   This is a 57 yo male with morbid obesity, OSA, DM, Afib, CHF, here with
   altered mental status leading to intubation, now transferred from
   [**Hospital Ward Name 57**] for MRI.
   # Altered mental status:
   Unclear etiology. Hypercarbia would not be wholly unexpected in this
   patient given his body habitus.  EEG results from [**3-7**]: abnormal in
   waking and sleeping states, with finding which can be seen with mild
   encephalopathy, medication effect, or extreme drowsiness. No focal
   abnormalities or epileptiform features.  MRI unable to be performed as
   patient was too large for scanner. Repeat CT scan to look for cerebral
   edema or evidence of anoxic brain injury unable to be performed due to
   patient
s weight.  Extubated on [**3-12**], mental status assessed and patient
   alert and able to follow commands but non-verbal.  Did not appear
   appropriate after extubation from mental status perspective, was
   reintubated shortly thereafter.  Etiology of AMS remains unclear at
   this point.  Infx vs. hypoxic/ischemic still not clear. Head CT from
   [**2124-3-14**] was negative. Remains on abx for meningitis.
   - Cont sedation with fent/versed
   - Continue vanco / ceftriaxone / acyclovir empirically at meningitis
   doses with last dose of all antibiotics to be given on [**2124-3-20**]
   - Neurology following
   # Respiratory failure:
   Likely intubated in order to protect airway in setting of altered
   mental status. Patient is s/p difficult intubation using fiberoptic
   scope for intubation.  Extubated on [**3-12**], required reintubation with
   awake fiberoptic by anesthesia later in the PM on [**3-12**] due to worsening
   tachypnea despite BiPAP.  Mini-BAL performed [**3-13**] with no growth on
   final culture. Patient being maintained on PSV 10/10 now. Ongoing
   diuresis. Any attempt at extubation will require anesthesia on standby
   with airway kit and may require fiberoptic guided reintubation.
   - Cont intubation for now, trial of lower PSV this evening.
   - Will start diamox if hypercarbia >40
   - Cont fent/versed for sedation
   - Cont lasix gtt, currently at 6 mg/hr,  goal CVP 10-20
   - Will start to discuss possibility of trach with HCP if fails
   extubation for second time
   # Leukocytosis:
   WBC count has been fluctuating. Elevated WBC at presentation raises the
   possibility of infection as cause of AMS. Urine negative. ? RUL
   infiltrate on CXR, however poor study and difficult to interpret.
   Sputum culture only with growth of oropharyngeal flora. Unable to
   assess for h/o meningismus and therefore started on empiric treatment
   for this. BAL from [**3-13**] is negative at final culture result. All urine
   cultures negative. Only blood cultures still pending, but still with
   NGTD.
   - Follow-up pending blood cultures.
   - Vanc / ceftriaxone / acyclovir to cover meningitis given that we were
   unable to obtain any signs or symptoms of meningitis. Will cont empiric
   treatment for 2 week course ending on [**2124-3-20**]
   # Atrial fib:
   Patient in A-fib with history of RVR in this hospitalization. Currenly
   well-controlled on oral diltiazem.
   - Cont diltiazem 60mg four times per day
   - No coumadin [**1-10**] poor compliance.
   # CHF:
   Per history.  Difficult to assess volume status in this patient due to
   obesity. Received lasix at OSH for ? CHF. CVPs appear to be in mid to
   high teens.
   - Continue diuresis with furosemide gtt to attempt to get patient back
   to even fluid balance for length of stay
   # Psoriasis:
   Extensive.
   - On topical agents per most recent VA DC summary.
   # Diabetes
   Well-controlled at this time on HISS; long acting if needed.
   ICU Care

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 57-year-old male with morbid obesity, OSA, DM, Afib, CHF, and altered mental status (AMS) leading to intubation. The patient was transferred from a hospital ward for MRI, but the MRI was unable to be performed due to the patient's size.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory support: The patient is intubated and on CPAP/PSV with a tidal volume of 379 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 25 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 60%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which is well-controlled on oral diltiazem. The patient's cardiac status is difficult to assess due to obesity.
* Neurological: The patient's altered mental status is unclear in etiology, with EEG results showing mild encephalopathy, medication effect, or extreme drowsiness. The patient was extubated on [**3-12**] but required reintubation due to worsening tachypnea.
* Infectious: The patient has leukocytosis, and urine cultures are negative. The patient has been empirically treated for meningitis with vancomycin, ceftriaxone, and acyclovir.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may worsen due to the patient's obesity and altered mental status.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, and the patient's cardiac status is difficult to assess due to obesity.
* Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status may progress to more severe encephalopathy or anoxic brain injury.
* Infectious complications: The patient's empiric treatment for meningitis may not be effective, and the patient may develop further infections.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's obesity may lead to gastrointestinal complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding or obstruction.

The plan for the patient includes:

* Continuing intubation and mechanical ventilation
* Continuing empiric treatment for meningitis with vancomycin, ceftriaxone, and acyclovir
* Monitoring the patient's respiratory status and adjusting ventilation as necessary
* Monitoring the patient's cardiac status and adjusting treatment as necessary
* Monitoring the patient's neurological status and adjusting treatment as necessary
* Considering tracheostomy if the patient fails extubation for the second time.

9. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate levels and white blood cell count may indicate sepsis, which needs to be ruled out and managed accordingly.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue monitoring their vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory status closely, and to adjust their treatment plan as needed to prevent further complications.

The patient is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, sedatives, and pain management medications. They have a central line, multi-lumen, and are receiving IV fluids. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3Â°C, heart rate of 83 bpm, and blood pressure of 133/74 mmHg. They are receiving oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to their underlying condition and the need for mechanical ventilation.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure and altered mental status may increase their risk of developing pneumonia.
3. Sepsis: The patient's malnutrition, electrolyte and fluid disorder, and impaired skin integrity may increase their risk of developing sepsis.
4. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation may increase their risk of developing cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure or cardiac arrest.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's malnutrition and altered mental status may increase their risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as aspiration pneumonia or gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Infection: The patient's central line and multi-lumen may increase their risk of developing infection.
7. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status may progress to delirium, which can worsen their condition.
8. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition may worsen if they are not receiving adequate nutrition.
9. Electrolyte and Fluid Disorder: The patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder may worsen if they are not receiving adequate treatment.
10. Skin Integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity may worsen if they are not receiving adequate wound care.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 57 yo male with morbid obesity, OSA, DM, Afib, CHF, here with
   altered mental status leading to intubation, now transferred from
   [**Hospital Ward Name 57**] for MRI.
   # Altered mental status:
   Unclear etiology. Hypercarbia would not be wholly unexpected in this
   patient given his body habitus.  EEG results from [**3-7**]: abnormal in
   waking and sleeping states, with finding which can be seen with mild
   encephalopathy, medication effect, or extreme drowsiness. No focal
   abnormalities or epileptiform features.  MRI unable to be performed as
   patient was too large for scanner. Repeat CT scan to look for cerebral
   edema or evidence of anoxic brain injury unable to be performed due to
   patient
s weight.  Extubated on [**3-12**], mental status assessed and patient
   alert and able to follow commands but non-verbal.  Did not appear
   appropriate after extubation from mental status perspective, was
   reintubated shortly thereafter.  Etiology of AMS remains unclear at
   this point.  Infx vs. hypoxic/ischemic still not clear. Head CT from
   [**2124-3-14**] was negative. Remains on abx for meningitis.
   - Cont sedation with fent/versed
   - treat with vanco / zosyn / acyclovir empirically, the switch from
   ceftriaxone to zosyn due to concern for vent assoc PNA (see below)
   # Respiratory failure:
   Likely intubated in order to protect airway in setting of altered
   mental status. Patient is s/p difficult intubation using fiberoptic
   scope for intubation.  Extubated on [**3-12**], required reintubation with
   awake fiberoptic by anesthesia later in the PM on [**3-12**] due to worsening
   tachypnea despite BiPAP.  Mini-BAL performed [**3-13**] with no growth on
   final culture. Patient being maintained on PSV 10/10 now. Ongoing
   diuresis. Any attempt at extubation will require anesthesia on standby
   with airway kit and may require fiberoptic guided reintubation.
   - Cont intubation for now.
   - check VBG, send sputum
   - as CXR is worse today, and sputum appears yellow/tan, would treat
   with vanc/zosyn for possible vent assoc PNA
   - Will start diamox if hypercarbia >40
   - Cont fent/versed for sedation
   - Cont lasix gtt, currently at 6 mg/hr,  goal CVP 10-20
   - Will start to discuss possibility of trach with HCP if fails
   extubation for second time
   # Leukocytosis:
   WBC count has been fluctuating. Elevated WBC at presentation raises the
   possibility of infection as cause of AMS. Urine negative. ? RUL
   infiltrate on CXR, however poor study and difficult to interpret.
   Sputum culture only with growth of oropharyngeal flora. Unable to
   assess for h/o meningismus and therefore started on empiric treatment
   for this. BAL from [**3-13**] is negative at final culture result. All urine
   cultures negative. Only blood cultures still pending, but still with
   NGTD.
   - Follow-up pending blood cultures.
   - Vanc / zosyn / acyclovir as above
   # Atrial fib:
   Patient in A-fib with history of RVR in this hospitalization. Currenly
   well-controlled on oral diltiazem.
   - Cont diltiazem 60mg four times per day
   - No coumadin [**1-10**] poor compliance.
   # CHF:
   Per history.  Difficult to assess volume status in this patient due to
   obesity. Received lasix at OSH for ? CHF. CVPs appear to be in mid to
   high teens.
   - Continue diuresis with furosemide gtt to attempt to get patient back
   to even fluid balance for length of stay
   # Psoriasis:
   Extensive.
   - On topical agents per most recent VA DC summary.
   # Diabetes
   Well-controlled at this time on HISS; long acting if needed.
   DISPO: brother [**Name (NI) **] listed as HCP
   ICU [**Name (NI) 81**]
   Nutrition:
   Replete with fiber Full strength; Additives: Beneprotein, 30 gm/day
   Glycemic Control:

   This is a 57 yo male with morbid obesity, OSA, DM, Afib, CHF, here with
   altered mental status leading to intubation, now transferred from
   [**Hospital Ward Name 57**] for MRI.
   # Altered mental status:
   Unclear etiology. Hypercarbia would not be wholly unexpected in this
   patient given his body habitus.  EEG results from [**3-7**]: abnormal in
   waking and sleeping states, with finding which can be seen with mild
   encephalopathy, medication effect, or extreme drowsiness. No focal
   abnormalities or epileptiform features.  MRI unable to be performed as
   patient was too large for scanner. Repeat CT scan to look for cerebral
   edema or evidence of anoxic brain injury unable to be performed due to
   patient
s weight.  Extubated on [**3-12**], mental status assessed and patient
   alert and able to follow commands but non-verbal.  Did not appear
   appropriate after extubation from mental status perspective, was
   reintubated shortly thereafter.  Etiology of AMS remains unclear at
   this point.  Infx vs. hypoxic/ischemic still not clear. Head CT from
   [**2124-3-14**] was negative. Remains on abx for meningitis.
   - Cont sedation with fent/versed
   - treat with vanco / zosyn / acyclovir empirically, the switch from
   ceftriaxone to zosyn due to concern for vent assoc PNA (see below)
   # Respiratory failure:
   Likely intubated in order to protect airway in setting of altered
   mental status. Patient is s/p difficult intubation using fiberoptic
   scope for intubation.  Extubated on [**3-12**], required reintubation with
   awake fiberoptic by anesthesia later in the PM on [**3-12**] due to worsening
   tachypnea despite BiPAP.  Mini-BAL performed [**3-13**] with no growth on
   final culture. Patient being maintained on PSV 10/10 now. Ongoing
   diuresis. Any attempt at extubation will require anesthesia on standby
   with airway kit and may require fiberoptic guided reintubation.
   - Cont intubation for now.
   - check VBG, send sputum
   - as CXR is worse today, and sputum appears yellow/tan, would treat
   with vanc/zosyn for possible vent assoc PNA
   - Will start diamox if hypercarbia >40
   - Cont fent/versed for sedation
   - Cont lasix gtt, currently at 6 mg/hr,  goal CVP 10-20
   - Will start to discuss possibility of trach with HCP if fails
   extubation for second time
   # Leukocytosis:
   WBC count has been fluctuating. Elevated WBC at presentation raises the
   possibility of infection as cause of AMS. Urine negative. ? RUL
   infiltrate on CXR, however poor study and difficult to interpret.
   Sputum culture only with growth of oropharyngeal flora. Unable to
   assess for h/o meningismus and therefore started on empiric treatment
   for this. BAL from [**3-13**] is negative at final culture result. All urine
   cultures negative. Only blood cultures still pending, but still with
   NGTD.
   - Follow-up pending blood cultures.
   - Vanc / zosyn / acyclovir as above
   # Atrial fib:
   Patient in A-fib with history of RVR in this hospitalization. Currenly
   well-controlled on oral diltiazem.
   - Cont diltiazem 60mg four times per day
   - No coumadin [**1-10**] poor compliance.
   # CHF:
   Per history.  Difficult to assess volume status in this patient due to
   obesity. Received lasix at OSH for ? CHF. CVPs appear to be in mid to
   high teens.
   - Continue diuresis with furosemide gtt to attempt to get patient back
   to even fluid balance for length of stay
   # Psoriasis:
   Extensive.
   - On topical agents per most recent VA DC summary.
   # Diabetes
   Well-controlled at this time on HISS; long acting if needed.
   DISPO: brother [**Name (NI) **] listed as HCP

Based on the progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress as follows:

The patient is a 57-year-old male with morbid obesity, OSA, DM, Afib, CHF, and altered mental status (AMS) who was intubated and transferred to the ICU. He has a history of difficult intubation and has been maintained on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode. The patient has been on various antibiotics, including ceftriaxone, vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam, and acyclovir, due to concerns for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and possible meningitis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4Â°C (99.4Â°F), heart rate of 85 beats per minute, blood pressure of 142/71 mmHg, respiratory rate of 8 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. His laboratory results show mild leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 9.4-12.6 x 10^9/L. His blood cultures are pending, but his urine cultures have been negative.

The patient's physical examination is notable for attenuated breath sounds, clear to auscultation anteriorly, and irregular atrial fibrillation. His neurological examination shows him to be awake and following commands, but non-verbal.

The patient's medical history is significant for morbid obesity, OSA, DM, Afib, and CHF. He has a history of psoriasis and is on topical agents. He has a family history of CHF and has been taking oral diltiazem for atrial fibrillation.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's history of difficult intubation and prolonged mechanical ventilation, he is at risk for developing VAP.
2. Meningitis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and positive sputum culture raise concerns for possible meningitis.
3. Hypercarbia: The patient's obesity and altered mental status increase his risk for developing hypercarbia, which can lead to respiratory failure and other complications.
4. Cerebral edema or anoxic brain injury: The patient's altered mental status and history of difficult intubation increase his risk for developing cerebral edema or anoxic brain injury.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's history of cough and fever raises concerns for possible pneumonia.
6. DVT: The patient's obesity and immobility increase his risk for developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
7. Stress ulcer: The patient's history of altered mental status and prolonged mechanical ventilation increase his risk for developing stress ulcer.

In terms of management, the patient is being treated with antibiotics empirically for possible VAP and meningitis. He is being maintained on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, and his sedation is being managed with fentanyl and midazolam. His fluid balance is being monitored, and he is being treated with diuretics to attempt to get him back to even fluid balance. His nutritional needs are being met with enteral nutrition, and his glycemic control is being monitored.

   This is a 57 yo male with morbid obesity, OSA, DM, Afib, CHF, here with
   altered mental status leading to intubation, now transferred from
   [**Hospital Ward Name 57**] for MRI.
   # Altered mental status:
   Unclear etiology. Hypercarbia would not be wholly unexpected in this
   patient given his body habitus.  EEG results from [**3-7**]: abnormal in
   waking and sleeping states, with finding which can be seen with mild
   encephalopathy, medication effect, or extreme drowsiness. No focal
   abnormalities or epileptiform features.  MRI unable to be performed as
   patient was too large for scanner. Repeat CT scan to look for cerebral
   edema or evidence of anoxic brain injury unable to be performed due to
   patient
s weight.  Extubated on [**3-12**], mental status assessed and patient
   alert and able to follow commands but non-verbal.  Did not appear
   appropriate after extubation from mental status perspective, was
   reintubated shortly thereafter.  Etiology of AMS remains unclear at
   this point.  Infx vs. hypoxic/ischemic still not clear. Head CT from
   [**2124-3-14**] was negative. Remains on abx for meningitis.  Now with
   ?infiltrate on CXR c/f VAP, continued on abx.
   - Cont sedation with fent/versed
   - treat with vanco / zosyn / acyclovir empirically, the switch from
   ceftriaxone to zosyn due to concern for vent assoc PNA (see below).
   - will plan to treat for 7d course with vanco/zosyn for VAP, follow
   sputum cultures
   # Respiratory failure:
   Likely intubated in order to protect airway in setting of altered
   mental status. Patient is s/p difficult intubation using fiberoptic
   scope for intubation.  Extubated on [**3-12**], required reintubation with
   awake fiberoptic by anesthesia later in the PM on [**3-12**] due to worsening
   tachypnea despite BiPAP.  Mini-BAL performed [**3-13**] with no growth on
   final culture. Patient being maintained on PSV 10/10 now. Ongoing
   diuresis. Any attempt at extubation will require anesthesia on standby
   with airway kit and may require fiberoptic guided reintubation.  New
   c/f VAP given tan colored sputum.
   - Cont intubation for now.
   - will plan to pursue trach soon as pt without clear signs of
   improvement for successful
   - follow VBG daily, f/u cultures
   - Cont tx with vanc/zosyn for possible vent assoc PNA
   - start diamox today for CO2 39
   - Cont fent/versed for sedation
   - Cont lasix gtt, goal CVP 10-20
   - will start to pursue trach options
   # Leukocytosis:
   WBC count has been fluctuating. Elevated WBC at presentation raises the
   possibility of infection as cause of AMS. Urine negative. ? RUL
   infiltrate on CXR, however poor study and difficult to interpret.
   Sputum culture only with growth of oropharyngeal flora. Unable to

   for this. BAL from [**3-13**] is negative at final culture result. All urine
   cultures negative. Only blood cultures still pending, but still with

   - Follow-up pending blood cultures.
   - Vanc / zosyn / acyclovir as above
   # Atrial fib:
   Patient in A-fib with history of RVR in this hospitalization. Currenly
   well-controlled on oral diltiazem.
   - Cont diltiazem 60mg four times per day
   - No coumadin [**1-10**] poor compliance.
   # CHF:
   Per history.  Difficult to assess volume status in this patient due to
   obesity. Received lasix at OSH for ? CHF. CVPs appear to be in mid to
   high teens.
   - Continue diuresis with furosemide gtt to attempt to get patient back
   to even fluid balance for length of stay

   Extensive.
   - On topical agents per most recent VA DC summary.

**Summary:**

The patient is a 57-year-old male with a complex medical history, including morbid obesity, obstructive sleep apnea, diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and congestive heart failure. He was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, which was initially unclear in etiology. The patient was intubated and received antibiotics for meningitis. A recent chest x-ray showed a possible infiltrate, leading to a concern for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient is currently being treated with vancomycin, zosyn, and acyclovir empirically.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's chest x-ray shows a possible infiltrate, and the patient is at high risk for VAP due to his prolonged mechanical ventilation.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he requires ongoing diuresis and sedation to manage his airway.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count has been fluctuating, which may indicate an underlying infection or inflammation.
4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is poorly controlled, and he requires ongoing treatment with diltiazem.
5. Congestive heart failure: The patient's congestive heart failure is difficult to assess due to his obesity, and he requires ongoing diuresis to manage his fluid balance.
6. Meningitis: The patient is at risk for meningitis due to his altered mental status and the presence of oropharyngeal flora in his sputum.
7. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for sepsis due to his multiple comorbidities and the presence of an unknown infiltrate on his chest x-ray.
8. Pneumonia: The patient's chest x-ray shows a possible infiltrate, which may indicate pneumonia.

**Plan:**

1. Continue treatment for VAP with vancomycin, zosyn, and acyclovir empirically.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust sedation and diuresis as needed.
3. Consider tracheostomy to facilitate weaning from mechanical ventilation.
4. Continue antibiotics for meningitis and monitor for signs of sepsis.
5. Monitor the patient's leukocytosis and consider further evaluation for underlying infection or inflammation.
6. Continue treatment for atrial fibrillation with diltiazem.
7. Monitor the patient's congestive heart failure and adjust diuresis as needed.
8. Consider further evaluation for the underlying cause of the patient's altered mental status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient remains intubated and is being treated for presumed meningitis, acute respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation, and biventricular congestive heart failure. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3Â°C, heart rate of 79 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 122/79 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support includes CPAP/PSV ventilation with a tidal volume of 584 mL and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 60%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and troponin-T, indicating possible inflammatory response and cardiac injury. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly low potassium level.

The patient's medications include antibiotics for presumed meningitis, anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation, and diuretics for congestive heart failure. The patient's nutrition is being provided through total parenteral nutrition (TPN) with fiber supplementation.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure can worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise and potential respiratory arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient's presumed meningitis and elevated LDH levels may indicate a severe infection, which can lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation can worsen, leading to cardiac arrest or stroke.
4. Congestive heart failure: The patient's biventricular congestive heart failure can worsen, leading to further cardiac compromise and potential cardiac arrest.
5. Infection: The patient's presumed meningitis can lead to a central nervous system infection, which can have serious consequences.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's elevated LDH levels and potential coagulopathy may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Renal failure: The patient's electrolyte imbalance and potential sepsis can lead to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical condition to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient remains intubated and is being treated for presumptive meningitis. They are receiving antibiotics, including Ceftriaxone, Vancomycin, Piperacillin/Tazobactam, and Acyclovir. The patient is also receiving sedation with Midazolam and Fentanyl, as well as diuretic therapy with Furosemide.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3Â°C, heart rate of 79 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 122/79 mmHg. Their respiratory support includes a CPAP/PSV ventilator mode, with a tidal volume of 584 mL and a PEEP of 12 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and creatinine levels, as well as decreased platelet count. Their blood cultures are pending.

The patient's physical examination reveals obesity, arousability, and decreased breath sounds. They have diffuse psoriatic changes on their skin.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for developing VAP due to their prolonged intubation.
2. Meningitis-related complications: The patient's presumptive meningitis diagnosis requires close monitoring for potential complications, such as increased intracranial pressure, seizures, and neurological deficits.
3. Septic shock: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and creatinine levels may indicate a potential septic shock, which requires prompt recognition and treatment.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory support requires close monitoring for potential complications, such as hypoxia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and biventricular CHF require close monitoring for potential complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiogenic shock.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's prolonged intubation and antibiotic therapy may increase their risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as Clostridioides difficile infection and antibiotic-associated diarrhea.
7. Skin complications: The patient's psoriasis requires close monitoring for potential complications, such as skin infections and allergic reactions to topical creams.
8. Endocrine complications: The patient's diabetes mellitus requires close monitoring for potential complications, such as hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of their presumptive meningitis, respiratory failure, and cardiovascular complications, as well as ongoing assessment for potential complications.

   This is a 57 yo male with morbid obesity, OSA, DM, Afib, CHF, here with
   altered mental status leading to intubation, now transferred from
   [**Hospital Ward Name 57**] for MRI.
   # Altered mental status:
   Unclear etiology. Hypercarbia would not be wholly unexpected in this
   patient given his body habitus.  EEG results from [**3-7**]: abnormal in
   waking and sleeping states, with finding which can be seen with mild
   encephalopathy, medication effect, or extreme drowsiness. No focal
   abnormalities or epileptiform features.  MRI unable to be performed as
   patient was too large for scanner. Repeat CT scan to look for cerebral
   edema or evidence of anoxic brain injury unable to be performed due to
   patient
s weight.  Extubated on [**3-12**], mental status assessed and patient
   alert and able to follow commands but non-verbal.  Did not appear
   appropriate after extubation from mental status perspective, was
   reintubated shortly thereafter.  Etiology of AMS remains unclear at
   this point.  Infx vs. hypoxic/ischemic still not clear. Head CT from
   [**2124-3-14**] was negative. Remains on abx for meningitis.  Now with
   ?infiltrate on CXR c/f VAP, continued on abx.  Improved mental status
   off sedation.  Self extubated on [**3-19**] AM with stable resp function
   post-extubation.  Able to follow complex commands post-extubation,
   talking and responsive.
   - treat with vanco / zosyn / acyclovir empirically, the switch from
   ceftriaxone to zosyn due to concern for vent assoc PNA (see below).
   - will plan to treat for 7d course with vanco/zosyn for VAP, follow
   sputum cultures
   # Respiratory failure:
   Likely intubated in order to protect airway in setting of altered
   mental status. Patient is s/p difficult intubation using fiberoptic
   scope for intubation.  Extubated on [**3-12**], required reintubation with
   awake fiberoptic by anesthesia later in the PM on [**3-12**] due to worsening
   tachypnea despite BiPAP.  Mini-BAL performed [**3-13**] with no growth on
   final culture. Patient being maintained on PSV 10/10 now. Ongoing
   diuresis. Any attempt at extubation will require anesthesia on standby
   with airway kit and may require fiberoptic guided reintubation.  New
   c/f VAP given tan colored sputum.  Self extubated on [**3-19**] AM, stable
   resp status post-extubation, placed on BiPAP prophylactically, ABG
   stable.
   - patient stable post self-extubation, will follow q2hr VBG
   - close monitoring of respiratory status.
   - follow VBG daily, f/u cultures
   - Cont tx with vanc/zosyn for possible vent assoc PNA
   - d/c diamox now that patient is extubated
   - Cont lasix gtt, goal CVP 10-20
   # Leukocytosis:
   WBC count has been fluctuating. Elevated WBC at presentation raises the
   possibility of infection as cause of AMS. Urine negative. ? RUL
   infiltrate on CXR, however poor study and difficult to interpret.
   Sputum culture only with growth of oropharyngeal flora. Unable to
   assess for h/o meningismus and therefore started on empiric treatment
   for this. BAL from [**3-13**] is negative at final culture result. All urine
   cultures negative. Only blood cultures still pending, but still with
   NGTD.
   - Follow-up pending blood cultures.
   - Vanc / zosyn / acyclovir as above
   - will plan to d/c acyclovir tomorrow, cont vanc/zosyn for full 7d VAP
   course
   # Atrial fib:
   Patient in A-fib with history of RVR in this hospitalization. Currenly
   well-controlled on oral diltiazem.
   - will start Diltiazem gtt today now that NGT pulled during self
   extubation.
   - No coumadin [**1-10**] poor compliance.
   # CHF:
   Per history.  Difficult to assess volume status in this patient due to
   obesity. Received lasix at OSH for ? CHF. CVPs appear to be in mid to
   high teens.
   - Continue diuresis with furosemide gtt to attempt to get patient back
   to even fluid balance for length of stay
   # Psoriasis:
   Extensive.
   - On topical agents per most recent VA DC summary.
   # Diabetes
   Well-controlled at this time on HISS; long acting if needed.

Based on the provided progress note, I will summarize the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 57-year-old male with morbid obesity, obstructive sleep apnea, diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and congestive heart failure, who was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status. He was intubated and required a difficult intubation using a fiberoptic scope. The patient was treated with antibiotics for suspected meningitis and was started on empiric treatment for vent-associated pneumonia (VAP). He was extubated on [**3-12**] but required reintubation due to worsening tachypnea. The patient self-extubated on [**3-19**] and was placed on BiPAP prophylactically.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **VAP:** The patient has a new diagnosis of VAP, which is a serious and potentially life-threatening complication. He is being treated with vancomycin and Zosyn, and his sputum cultures will be followed.
2. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he requires close monitoring. He has been extubated and placed on BiPAP, but any attempt at extubation will require anesthesia on standby.
3. **Leukocytosis:** The patient's WBC count has been fluctuating, and elevated WBC at presentation raises the possibility of infection as a cause of altered mental status.
4. **Atrial Fibrillation:** The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently in atrial fibrillation with a history of RVR. His medication regimen includes oral diltiazem, and he will start diltiazem gtt today.
5. **CHF:** The patient has a history of CHF, and his volume status is difficult to assess due to obesity. He is receiving diuresis with furosemide gtt to attempt to get his fluid balance back to normal.
6. **Infection:** The patient has a high risk of infection due to his morbid obesity, altered mental status, and respiratory failure. He is receiving empiric treatment for meningitis and VAP, and his blood cultures are pending.
7. **Nutritional Deficiencies:** The patient's nutritional status is compromised due to his obesity and altered mental status. He requires close monitoring of his glycemic control and nutrition.
8. **Psoriasis:** The patient has extensive psoriasis and is being treated with topical agents.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue empiric treatment for VAP and meningitis.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider reintubation if necessary.
3. Continue diuresis with furosemide gtt to attempt to get the patient's fluid balance back to normal.
4. Monitor the patient's WBC count and consider further evaluation for infection.
5. Continue treatment for atrial fibrillation with oral diltiazem and consider starting diltiazem gtt.
6. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and glycemic control closely.
7. Consider further evaluation for psoriasis and its impact on the patient's overall health.

* Temperature: 37.1Â°C (98.7Â°F)
* Heart rate: 124 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 140/72 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 25 inspirations per minute (insp/min)

The patient has been on invasive ventilation and has had an unplanned extubation, which was managed with non-invasive ventilation. They have also been receiving antibiotics, including ceftriaxone, vancomycin, acyclovir, and piperacillin/tazobactam.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 12.6-13.7 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 12.5-13.7 g/dL

The patient's physical examination shows:

* Peripheral vascular: Not assessed
* Skin: Not assessed
* Neurologic: Responds to verbal commands, but movement, tone, and reflexes are not assessed

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Malnutrition
* Electrolyte and fluid disorder
* Altered mental status (not delirium)
* Impaired skin integrity
* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

* Nutrition: Enteral nutrition
* Glycemic control: Tight glycemic control
* Lines: Multi-lumen catheter
* Prophylaxis: DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP prophylaxis

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Pneumonia due to prolonged mechanical ventilation
* Ventilator-associated lung injury (VALI)
* Respiratory failure due to inadequate oxygenation or ventilation
* Electrolyte imbalances due to fluid and electrolyte disorders
* Malnutrition and related complications
* Skin breakdown and pressure ulcers
* Delirium or altered mental status due to underlying medical conditions or medications
* Cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest, due to atrial fibrillation and other cardiac conditions.

The patient has a diagnosis of malnutrition, electrolyte and fluid disorder, altered mental status (not delirium), impaired skin integrity, and respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS).

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Glycemic control: The patient will receive insulin therapy to maintain blood glucose levels within a normal range.

* Prophylaxis: The patient will receive prophylactic anticoagulation therapy to prevent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer prophylaxis to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding.

6. VAP: The patient's VAP prophylaxis may not be effective in preventing pneumonia.
7. DVT: The patient's prophylactic anticoagulation therapy may not be effective in preventing DVT.
8. Stress ulcer: The patient's stress ulcer prophylaxis may not be effective in preventing gastrointestinal bleeding.
9. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen if not properly managed.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 57 yo male with morbid obesity, OSA, DM, Afib, CHF, here with
   altered mental status leading to intubation, now transferred from
   [**Hospital Ward Name 57**] for MRI.
   # Altered mental status:
   Unclear etiology. Hypercarbia would not be wholly unexpected in this
   patient given his body habitus.  EEG results from [**3-7**]: abnormal in
   waking and sleeping states, with finding which can be seen with mild
   encephalopathy, medication effect, or extreme drowsiness. No focal
   abnormalities or epileptiform features.  MRI unable to be performed as
   patient was too large for scanner. Repeat CT scan to look for cerebral
   edema or evidence of anoxic brain injury unable to be performed due to
   patient
s weight.  Extubated on [**3-12**], mental status assessed and patient
   alert and able to follow commands but non-verbal.  Did not appear
   appropriate after extubation from mental status perspective, was
   reintubated shortly thereafter.  Etiology of AMS remains unclear at
   this point.  Infx vs. hypoxic/ischemic still not clear. Head CT from
   [**2124-3-14**] was negative. Remains on abx for meningitis.  Now with
   ?infiltrate on CXR c/f VAP, continued on abx.  Improved mental status
   off sedation.  Self extubated on [**3-19**] AM with stable resp function
   post-extubation.  Able to follow complex commands post-extubation,
   talking and responsive.
   - treat with vanco / zosyn / acyclovir empirically, the switch from
   ceftriaxone to zosyn due to concern for vent assoc PNA (see below).
   - will plan to treat for 7d course with vanco/zosyn for VAP, follow
   sputum cultures
   # Respiratory failure:
   Likely intubated in order to protect airway in setting of altered
   mental status. Patient is s/p difficult intubation using fiberoptic
   scope for intubation.  Extubated on [**3-12**], required reintubation with
   awake fiberoptic by anesthesia later in the PM on [**3-12**] due to worsening
   tachypnea despite BiPAP.  Mini-BAL performed [**3-13**] with no growth on
   final culture. Patient being maintained on PSV 10/10 now. Ongoing
   diuresis. Any attempt at extubation will require anesthesia on standby
   with airway kit and may require fiberoptic guided reintubation.  New
   c/f VAP given tan colored sputum.  Self extubated on [**3-19**] AM, stable
   resp status post-extubation, placed on BiPAP prophylactically, ABG
   stable.
   - follow VBG daily, f/u cultures
   - Cont tx with vanc/zosyn for possible vent assoc PNA
   - cont diamox today for CO2 39
   - Cont lasix gtt, goal CVP 10-20
   # Leukocytosis:
   WBC count has been fluctuating. Elevated WBC at presentation raises the
   possibility of infection as cause of AMS. Urine negative. ? RUL
   infiltrate on CXR, however poor study and difficult to interpret.
   Sputum culture only with growth of oropharyngeal flora. Unable to
   assess for h/o meningismus and therefore started on empiric treatment
   for this. BAL from [**3-13**] is negative at final culture result. All urine
   cultures negative. Only blood cultures still pending, but still with
   NGTD.
   - Follow-up pending blood cultures.
   - Vanc / zosyn / acyclovir as above
   # Atrial fib:
   Patient in A-fib with history of RVR in this hospitalization. Currenly
   well-controlled on oral diltiazem.
   - will start Diltiazem gtt today now that NGT pulled during self
   extubation.
   - No coumadin [**1-10**] poor compliance.
   # CHF:
   Per history.  Difficult to assess volume status in this patient due to
   obesity. Received lasix at OSH for ? CHF. CVPs appear to be in mid to
   high teens.
   - Continue diuresis with furosemide gtt to attempt to get patient back
   to even fluid balance for length of stay
   # Psoriasis:
   Extensive.
   - On topical agents per most recent VA DC summary.
   # Diabetes
   Well-controlled at this time on HISS; long acting if needed.
   DISPO: brother [**Name (NI) **] listed as HCP
   ICU [**Name (NI) 81**]

   Likely intubated in order to protect airway in setting of altered
   mental status. Patient is s/p difficult intubation using fiberoptic
   scope for intubation.  Extubated on [**3-12**], required reintubation with
   awake fiberoptic by anesthesia later in the PM on [**3-12**] due to worsening
   tachypnea despite BiPAP.  Mini-BAL performed [**3-13**] with no growth on
   final culture. Patient being maintained on PSV 10/10 now. Ongoing
   diuresis. Any attempt at extubation will require anesthesia on standby
   with airway kit and may require fiberoptic guided reintubation.  New
   c/f VAP given tan colored sputum.  Self extubated on [**3-19**] AM, stable
   resp status post-extubation, placed on BiPAP prophylactically, ABG
   stable.
   - follow VBG daily, f/u cultures
   - Cont tx with vanc/zosyn for possible vent assoc PNA
   - cont diamox today for CO2 39
   - Cont lasix gtt, goal CVP 10-20
   # Leukocytosis:
   WBC count has been fluctuating. Elevated WBC at presentation raises the
   possibility of infection as cause of AMS. Urine negative. ? RUL
   infiltrate on CXR, however poor study and difficult to interpret.
   Sputum culture only with growth of oropharyngeal flora. Unable to
   assess for h/o meningismus and therefore started on empiric treatment
   for this. BAL from [**3-13**] is negative at final culture result. All urine
   cultures negative. Only blood cultures still pending, but still with
   NGTD.
   - Follow-up pending blood cultures.
   - Vanc / zosyn / acyclovir as above
   # Atrial fib:
   Patient in A-fib with history of RVR in this hospitalization. Currenly
   well-controlled on oral diltiazem.
   - will start Diltiazem gtt today now that NGT pulled during self
   extubation.
   - No coumadin [**1-10**] poor compliance.
   # CHF:
   Per history.  Difficult to assess volume status in this patient due to
   obesity. Received lasix at OSH for ? CHF. CVPs appear to be in mid to
   high teens.
   - Continue diuresis with furosemide gtt to attempt to get patient back
   to even fluid balance for length of stay
   # Psoriasis:
   Extensive.
   - On topical agents per most recent VA DC summary.
   # Diabetes
   Well-controlled at this time on HISS; long acting if needed.
   DISPO: brother [**Name (NI) **] listed as HCP
   ICU [**Name (NI) 81**]

Summary:

The patient is a 57-year-old male with morbid obesity, OSA, DM, Afib, and CHF, who was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status (AMS) leading to intubation. He was transferred from the hospital ward for an MRI, which was unable to be performed due to his large size. The patient's mental status has improved off sedation, and he is now able to follow complex commands and communicate verbally. He was extubated on [**3-12**] but required reintubation due to worsening tachypnea. He has been diagnosed with VAP and is being treated with vancomycin, zosyn, and acyclovir empirically.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infection: The patient's WBC count has been fluctuating, and he has been treated for meningitis and VAP. Further blood cultures are pending.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is at risk for respiratory failure due to his obesity and the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation.
3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's Afib is poorly controlled, and he has a history of RVR in this hospitalization. He is currently being treated with oral diltiazem.
4. Congestive Heart Failure: The patient has a history of CHF, and his fluid status is difficult to assess due to his obesity.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient's WBC count is elevated, which may indicate infection or inflammation.
6. Psoriasis: The patient has extensive psoriasis and is being treated with topical agents.
7. Diabetes: The patient has well-controlled diabetes, but he is at risk for complications due to his obesity and prolonged hospitalization.

Recommendations:

1. Continue treatment for VAP with vancomycin, zosyn, and acyclovir.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider tracheostomy if prolonged mechanical ventilation is required.
3. Adjust the patient's anticoagulation therapy to ensure adequate control of his Afib.
4. Continue diuresis with furosemide to attempt to get the patient back to even fluid balance.
5. Monitor the patient's WBC count and consider further evaluation for infection or inflammation.
6. Continue treatment for psoriasis with topical agents.
7. Monitor the patient's glucose levels and adjust his diabetes therapy as needed.

The patient is a 72-inch tall individual with a significant history of bronchial asthma, hypertension, and psoriasis. They were admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, respiratory failure, and atrial fibrillation. The patient has been treated presumptively for meningitis and started on antibiotics. They have also been started on Zosyn for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.6Â°C, heart rate of 102 bpm, and blood pressure of 122/70 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support includes non-invasive ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a Vt of 881 mL and a PS of 10 cmH2O.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Meningitis: The patient's altered mental status and respiratory failure may be related to meningitis. The patient is being treated presumptively for meningitis, but it is essential to monitor their condition closely for any signs of worsening or complications.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is being treated with non-invasive ventilation, but it is crucial to monitor their oxygenation and ventilation status closely to prevent further deterioration.
3. VAP: The patient's VAP is being treated with Zosyn, but it is essential to monitor their lung function and respiratory status closely to prevent further complications.
4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is being treated with dilt, but it is essential to monitor their heart rhythm and cardiac function closely to prevent further complications.
5. Biventricular CHF: The patient's biventricular CHF is being treated with diuretics, but it is essential to monitor their cardiac function and fluid status closely to prevent further complications.
6. DM: The patient's DM is being treated with insulin, but it is essential to monitor their blood glucose levels closely to prevent hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.
7. ICU Care: The patient's ICU care is being managed by the ICU team, but it is essential to monitor their condition closely and adjust their care plan as needed to prevent further complications.

5. Meningitis: The patient is being treated presumptively for meningitis, and it is essential to continue antibiotics and monitor for further complications.
6. Diabetes mellitus: The patient's diabetes mellitus is a significant concern, and it is essential to continue insulin and monitor for further complications, such as hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.
7. Psoriasis: The patient's psoriasis is a significant concern, and it is essential to continue creams and monitor for further complications, such as infection or skin breakdown.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical conditions, and it is essential to monitor and manage these conditions closely to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-inch tall individual with significant bra and a history of atrial fibrillation, psoriasis, and diabetes mellitus. The patient was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, respiratory distress, and biventricular congestive heart failure.

Over the past 24 hours, the patient experienced unplanned extubation and was started on non-invasive ventilation (NIV) with a BiPAP device. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 102 beats per minute, blood pressure of 122/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94%.

The patient has received various medications, including antibiotics (Ceftriaxone, Vancomycin, and Piperacillin/Tazobactam), antivirals (Acyclovir), and diuretics (Furosemide and Lasix). The patient is also receiving prophylactic medications, such as Heparin Sodium and Midazolam.

The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia, leukocytosis, and thrombocytopenia. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level.

The patient's respiratory support is being managed with NIV, with a ventilator mode of CPAP/PSV, and a FiO2 of 60%. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a pH of 7.40, pCO2 of 54 mmHg, and pO2 of 125 mmHg.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and requirement for NIV may lead to respiratory failure if not managed properly.
2. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's atrial fibrillation and biventricular congestive heart failure may lead to cardiovascular instability if not managed with close monitoring and medication adjustments.
3. Infection: The patient's altered mental status and respiratory distress may be related to an underlying infection, which may worsen if not treated promptly and effectively.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulant medications and presence of bleeding diathesis may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's diabetes mellitus and use of insulin may lead to hyperglycemia if not managed properly.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels may become imbalanced if not monitored and adjusted properly.
7. Pressure ulcers: The patient's prolonged stay in the ICU and use of prophylactic medications may increase the risk of pressure ulcers.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment plans as needed to prevent these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current health status as follows:

* The patient is a [age]-year-old male admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS), and atrial fibrillation.
* The patient has a history of meningitis, and antibiotics have been started presumptively.
* The patient is currently on non-invasive ventilation (BIPAP) after unplanned extubation, and the plan is to complete a 7-day course of antibiotics for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus, and insulin therapy is ongoing.
* The patient has a history of psoriasis, and topical creams are being used to manage the condition.
* The patient has a history of biventricular congestive heart failure, and diuresis is ongoing.
* The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and warfarin therapy has been started.
* The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated lactate levels.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Sepsis and septic shock due to meningitis and VAP
* Respiratory failure and worsening lung injury due to prolonged mechanical ventilation
* Cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest due to atrial fibrillation
* Renal failure due to inadequate fluid management and diuresis
* Worsening of biventricular congestive heart failure
* Development of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to immobility and lack of anticoagulation
* Worsening of psoriasis due to stress and inflammation
* Hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia due to insulin therapy and poor glycemic control

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical condition to prevent or manage these potential complications.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.1Â°C, heart rate of 81 bpm, and blood pressure of 142/74 mmHg. The patient has atrial fibrillation and is receiving heparin sodium for prophylaxis.

The patient has a significant medical history, including allergies to Precedex, and has received multiple antibiotics, including vancomycin, acyclovir, and piperacillin/tazobactam. The patient is receiving multiple medications, including diltiazem, midazolam, and heparin sodium.

The patient's laboratory results show abnormal values, including a white blood cell count of 12.5 K/uL, hemoglobin of 12.7 g/dL, and platelet count of 414 K/uL. The patient's electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with a potassium level of 4.2 mEq/L, sodium level of 138 mEq/L, and chloride level of 99 mEq/L.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's use of BiPAP therapy and their abnormal vital signs, such as a respiratory rate of 26 bpm, suggest that they may be at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's abnormal electrolyte levels, such as potassium, sodium, and chloride, may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, or other complications.
3. Fluid imbalance: The patient's fluid balance is abnormal, with a total fluid input of 2,880 mL and a total fluid output of 8,940 mL. This may lead to dehydration or fluid overload.
4. Infection: The patient's use of antibiotics and their abnormal laboratory results, such as a white blood cell count of 12.5 K/uL, may suggest that they are at risk for infection.
5. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition, as documented in their medical history, may lead to further complications, such as impaired wound healing, muscle weakness, or other nutritional deficiencies.
6. Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's abnormal electrolyte and fluid levels may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, or other complications.
7. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status, as documented in their medical history, may be a sign of a more serious underlying condition, such as sepsis, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
8. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity, as documented in their medical history, may be a sign of a more serious underlying condition, such as sepsis, and may require further evaluation and treatment.

Overall, the patient is at risk for multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 57 yo male with morbid obesity, OSA, DM, Afib, CHF, here with
   altered mental status leading to intubation, now transferred from
   [**Hospital Ward Name 57**] for MRI.
   # Altered mental status:
   Unclear etiology. Hypercarbia would not be wholly unexpected in this
   patient given his body habitus.  EEG results from [**3-7**]: abnormal in
   waking and sleeping states, with finding which can be seen with mild
   encephalopathy, medication effect, or extreme drowsiness. No focal
   abnormalities or epileptiform features.  MRI unable to be performed as
   patient was too large for scanner. Repeat CT scan to look for cerebral
   edema or evidence of anoxic brain injury unable to be performed due to
   patient
s weight.  Extubated on [**3-12**], mental status assessed and patient
   alert and able to follow commands but non-verbal.  Did not appear
   appropriate after extubation from mental status perspective, was
   reintubated shortly thereafter.  Etiology of AMS remains unclear at
   this point.  Infx vs. hypoxic/ischemic still not clear. Head CT from
   [**2124-3-14**] was negative. Remains on abx for meningitis.  Now with
   ?infiltrate on CXR c/f VAP, continued on abx.  Improved mental status
   off sedation.  Self extubated on [**3-19**] AM with stable resp function
   post-extubation.  Able to follow complex commands post-extubation,
   talking and responsive.
   - treat with vanco / zosyn / acyclovir empirically, the switch from
   ceftriaxone to zosyn due to concern for vent assoc PNA (see below).
   - will plan to treat for 7d course with vanco/zosyn for VAP, follow
   sputum cultures
   # Respiratory failure:
   Likely intubated in order to protect airway in setting of altered
   mental status. Patient is s/p difficult intubation using fiberoptic
   scope for intubation.  Extubated on [**3-12**], required reintubation with
   awake fiberoptic by anesthesia later in the PM on [**3-12**] due to worsening
   tachypnea despite BiPAP.  Mini-BAL performed [**3-13**] with no growth on
   final culture. Patient being maintained on PSV 10/10 now. Ongoing
   diuresis. Any attempt at extubation will require anesthesia on standby
   with airway kit and may require fiberoptic guided reintubation.  New
   c/f VAP given tan colored sputum.  Self extubated on [**3-19**] AM, stable
   resp status post-extubation, placed on BiPAP prophylactically, ABG
   stable.
   - patient stable post self-extubation, will follow q2hr VBG
   - close monitoring of respiratory status.
   - follow VBG daily, f/u cultures
   - Cont tx with vanc/zosyn for possible vent assoc PNA
   - d/c diamox now that patient is extubated
   - Cont lasix gtt, goal CVP 10-20
   # Leukocytosis:
   WBC count has been fluctuating. Elevated WBC at presentation raises the
   possibility of infection as cause of AMS. Urine negative. ? RUL
   infiltrate on CXR, however poor study and difficult to interpret.
   Sputum culture only with growth of oropharyngeal flora. Unable to
   assess for h/o meningismus and therefore started on empiric treatment
   for this. BAL from [**3-13**] is negative at final culture result. All urine
   cultures negative. Only blood cultures still pending, but still with
   NGTD.
   - Follow-up pending blood cultures.

Summary:

The patient is a 57-year-old male with morbid obesity, OSA, DM, Afib, CHF, who was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status (AMS) leading to intubation. He was transferred from a hospital ward for an MRI, which was unable to be performed due to his large size. The patient's mental status has been fluctuating, and he was extubated on [**3-12**] but required reintubation due to worsening tachypnea. He was recently self-extubated on [**3-19**] AM and is currently on BiPAP prophylactically.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient has a tan-colored sputum and a new infiltrate on CXR, which may indicate VAP. He is being treated with vancomycin, zosyn, and acyclovir empirically.
2. Infection: The patient's elevated WBC count and fluctuating WBC count raise the possibility of infection as a cause of AMS. Urine cultures have been negative, but blood cultures are pending.
3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient is in atrial fibrillation with a history of RVR in this hospitalization. His current medication regimen includes oral diltiazem, which may need to be adjusted.
4. CHF: The patient's history of CHF and difficult-to-assess volume status due to obesity may lead to fluid imbalance and complications.
5. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is currently stable, but he may require reintubation if his oxygenation or ventilation deteriorates.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient's fluctuating WBC count may indicate an underlying infection or inflammatory process.
7. Meningitis: The patient's sputum culture only grew oropharyngeal flora, and he was started on empiric treatment for meningitis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and be prepared for reintubation if necessary.
2. Follow up on pending blood cultures to determine the cause of the patient's AMS and infection.
3. Continue treatment for VAP and adjust antibiotics as necessary based on culture results.
4. Monitor the patient's fluid balance and adjust diuresis as needed to prevent complications.
5. Consider adjusting the patient's atrial fibrillation medication regimen to optimize his heart rate and rhythm.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his sedation and pain management as necessary.

   This is a 57 yo male with morbid obesity, OSA, DM, Afib, CHF, here with

   Unclear etiology. Hypercarbia would not be wholly unexpected in this

   waking and sleeping states, with finding which can be seen with mild
   encephalopathy, medication effect, or extreme drowsiness. No focal
   abnormalities or epileptiform features.  MRI unable to be performed as
   patient was too large for scanner. Repeat CT scan to look for cerebral
   edema or evidence of anoxic brain injury unable to be performed due to
   patient
s weight.  Extubated on [**3-12**], mental status assessed and patient
   alert and able to follow commands but non-verbal.  Did not appear
   appropriate after extubation from mental status perspective, was
   reintubated shortly thereafter.  Etiology of AMS remains unclear at
   this point.  Infx vs. hypoxic/ischemic still not clear. Head CT from
   [**2124-3-14**] was negative. Remains on abx for meningitis.  Now with
   ?infiltrate on CXR c/f VAP, continued on abx.  Improved mental status
   off sedation.  Self extubated on [**3-19**] AM with stable resp function
   post-extubation.  Able to follow complex commands post-extubation,
   talking and responsive.
   - will plan to d/c acyclovir today
   - will plan to treat for 7d course with vanco/zosyn (D1 [**3-20**]) for VAP,
   follow sputum cultures
   # Respiratory failure:
   Likely intubated in order to protect airway in setting of altered
   mental status. Patient is s/p difficult intubation using fiberoptic
   scope for intubation.  Extubated on [**3-12**], required reintubation with
   awake fiberoptic by anesthesia later in the PM on [**3-12**] due to worsening
   tachypnea despite BiPAP.  Mini-BAL performed [**3-13**] with no growth on
   final culture. Patient being maintained on PSV 10/10 now. Ongoing
   diuresis. Any attempt at extubation will require anesthesia on standby
   with airway kit and may require fiberoptic guided reintubation.  New
   c/f VAP given tan colored sputum.  Self extubated on [**3-19**] AM, stable
   resp status post-extubation, placed on BiPAP prophylactically, ABG
   stable.

d yesterday, will watch I/O for continued goal net

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 57-year-old male with a complex medical history, including morbid obesity, obstructive sleep apnea, diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and chronic heart failure. He was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, which was initially attributed to hypercarbia, but the etiology remains unclear. The patient was intubated and placed on BiPAP, but self-extubated at 0430, which was followed by reintubation.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a SpO2 of 96% and a VBG of 7.34/60. He is on BiPAP with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O and an FiO2 of 40%. The patient's blood gases are stable, with a pH of 7.4, PaCO2 of 31 mmHg, and PaO2 of 64 mmHg.

The patient's cardiac status is stable, with a heart rate of 81 bpm and a blood pressure of 142/74 mmHg. His atrial fibrillation is well-controlled on oral diltiazem.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, with a range of 12.5-14.0 K/uL. His creatinine level is 0.7 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 31 mg/dL. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits.

The patient's medication list includes diltiazem, midazolam, heparin, and vancomycin, which were discontinued yesterday. He is currently receiving insulin, vancomycin, and piperacillin-tazobactam.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he is at risk for respiratory failure due to his morbid obesity and history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has a tan-colored sputum, which may indicate VAP.
3. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and positive blood cultures may indicate an underlying infection.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be a sign of infection or inflammation.
5. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may increase his risk of stroke or cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Chronic heart failure: The patient's chronic heart failure may exacerbate his respiratory and cardiac status.
7. Diabetes: The patient's diabetes may increase his risk of complications, such as diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperglycemic hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Close monitoring of his respiratory status.
2. BiPAP as needed.
3. Follow-up VBG daily and sputum cultures.
4. Continue treatment with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for possible VAP.
5. Discontinue lasix gtt.
6. Restart diltiazem 60mg qid today and discontinue dilt gtt.
7. Follow-up pending blood cultures.
8. Continue empiric treatment for meningitis.
9. Monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his sedation as needed.

The patient's disposition is to the ICU, and his code status is full code. His brother is listed as his healthcare proxy.

Summary:

The patient is a 57-year-old male with obesity, OSA, AF, and psoriasis who was found down and intubated in the ED for airway protection. He has been treated empirically for meningitis and has been diuresed aggressively. The patient has been off bipap and is currently receiving respiratory support with nasal cannula and bipap mask. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 83 bpm, blood pressure of 150/82 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 93%. He has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently on diltiazem.

The patient has been experiencing respiratory failure, acute on chronic diastolic CHF, and has a history of leukocytosis. He has been treated for VAP and has completed his course of antibiotics. He is currently on a clear diet and will need to continue diuresis, suctioning, and bipap at night.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern, and he may require further respiratory support, such as mechanical ventilation, if his condition deteriorates.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may increase his risk of stroke and heart failure, and he may require further anticoagulation therapy.
3. Chronic diastolic CHF: The patient's chronic diastolic CHF may worsen if he does not receive adequate treatment, and he may require further diuresis and medications to manage his symptoms.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be a sign of an underlying infection or inflammation, and he may require further evaluation and treatment to address this issue.
5. VAP: The patient's VAP may increase his risk of respiratory failure and other complications, and he may require further treatment and monitoring to prevent these complications.
6. Psoriasis: The patient's psoriasis may worsen if he does not receive adequate treatment, and he may require further therapy to manage his symptoms.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and treatment to manage his multiple medical conditions.

s weight.  Extubated on [**3-12**], mental status assessed and patient

   post-extubation.  Able to follow complex commands post-extubation,
   talking and responsive.  Today [**3-21**] with new delirium with increased

   - empiric flagyl
   - s/p 14d course acyclovir (end date [**3-20**])
   - will plan to treat for 7d course with vanco/zosyn (D1 [**3-20**]) for VAP,

Summary:

The patient is a 57-year-old male with morbid obesity, OSA, DM, Afib, and CHF, who was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status (AMS) leading to intubation. He has a history of difficult intubation and has required reintubation on multiple occasions. The patient has been treated for meningitis with a 14-day course of acyclovir, and has been started on empiric treatment for VAP with vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam. He has also been treated for c-diff with flagyl. The patient's mental status has fluctuated, with periods of improvement and worsening. He has been extubated and reintubated multiple times, and is currently on bi-level positive airway pressure (BiPAP) therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's c-spine infiltrate on CXR and tan-colored sputum are concerning for VAP.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated WBC count and diarrhea may indicate a septic process.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's history of RVR and current A-fib may increase his risk of embolic events.
4. CHF: The patient's history of CHF and current volume overload may increase his risk of cardiogenic shock.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient's fluctuating WBC count may indicate an underlying infection or inflammatory process.
6. C-diff: The patient's diarrhea and elevated WBC count may indicate a c-diff infection.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of difficult intubation and repeated reintubation may increase his risk of respiratory failure.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's altered mental status remains unclear, and further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause. The patient's respiratory status will continue to be closely monitored, and he will be maintained on BiPAP therapy. The patient will be continued on empiric treatment for VAP and c-diff, and further evaluation of his leukocytosis and CHF will be performed. The patient's code status remains full code.

The patient is a 72-inch-tall individual with a history of atrial fibrillation, who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure. They have been receiving antibiotics, including Acyclovir, Vancomycin, and Piperacillin/Tazobactam, as well as other medications such as Heparin Sodium for prophylaxis. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5Â°C, heart rate of 91 bpm, and blood pressure of 138/66 mmHg. They are receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula and have a SpO2 of 95%. The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia, elevated white blood cell count, and mild elevation of liver enzymes. They have a code status of full code and are dispositioned for further care in the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and they require mechanical ventilation. Prolonged mechanical ventilation can lead to ventilator-associated lung injury and pneumonia.
2. Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's electrolyte and fluid balance are abnormal, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
3. Malnutrition: The patient is at risk for malnutrition due to their prolonged hospital stay and inadequate nutrition. Malnutrition can lead to impaired wound healing, muscle weakness, and increased risk of infection.
4. Impaired skin integrity: The patient has impaired skin integrity, which can lead to skin breakdown and infection.
5. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status can increase their risk of falls, medication errors, and other complications.
6. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to their compromised immune system and prolonged hospital stay. Infections can lead to sepsis, organ dysfunction, and mortality.
7. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, which can increase their risk of cardiac arrest and mortality.
8. Liver dysfunction: The patient's elevated liver enzymes can indicate liver dysfunction, which can lead to impaired metabolism and increased risk of bleeding.
9. Renal dysfunction: The patient's abnormal renal function can lead to impaired kidney function, which can increase their risk of electrolyte imbalance, acidosis, and mortality.

These potential complications require close monitoring and management to prevent and treat them effectively.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with a significant medical history. Over the past 24 hours, the patient's condition has remained unstable, with ongoing respiratory failure, altered mental status, and electrolyte/fluid disorders. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5Â°C, heart rate of 91 bpm, and blood pressure of 138/66 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support includes nasal cannula oxygen therapy, and their blood gases indicate a pH of 7.27.

The patient has a PICC line in place, which was removed due to the patient's delirium and attempt to pull it out. The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, antivirals, and vasopressors. The patient's laboratory results indicate ongoing electrolyte imbalances, including hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ongoing respiratory failure could lead to further deterioration in their condition, including the development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's ongoing electrolyte imbalances, including hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia, could lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
3. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition could lead to further deterioration in their condition, including impaired wound healing, decreased immune function, and increased risk of infection.
4. Delirium: The patient's ongoing delirium could lead to further agitation, increased risk of falls, and decreased ability to communicate effectively.
5. Skin integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity could lead to further complications, including infection, wound dehiscence, and delayed healing.
6. Bloodstream infections: The patient's PICC line removal could lead to the development of bloodstream infections, including sepsis and septic shock.
7. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's ongoing electrolyte imbalances could lead to cardiac arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia.

Given the patient's complex medical condition, ongoing monitoring and close observation are necessary to prevent and manage potential complications.

   Unclear etiology. Hypercarbia would not be wholly unexpected in this

   waking and sleeping states, with finding which can be seen with mild
   encephalopathy, medication effect, or extreme drowsiness. No focal

   patient was too large for scanner. Repeat CT scan to look for cerebral
   edema or evidence of anoxic brain injury unable to be performed due to
   patient
s weight.  Extubated on [**3-12**], mental status assessed and patient
   alert and able to follow commands but non-verbal.  Did not appear
   appropriate after extubation from mental status perspective, was
   reintubated shortly thereafter.  Etiology of AMS remains unclear at
   this point.  Infx vs. hypoxic/ischemic still not clear. Head CT from
   [**2124-3-14**] was negative. Remains on abx for meningitis.  Now with
   ?infiltrate on CXR c/f VAP, continued on abx.  Improved mental status
   off sedation.  Self extubated on [**3-19**] AM with stable resp function
   post-extubation.  Able to follow complex commands post-extubation,
   talking and responsive.  Today [**3-21**] with new delirium with increased
   WBC
   - c.diff
   - s/p 14d course acyclovir (end date [**3-20**])
   - will plan to treat for 7d course with vanco/zosyn (D1 [**3-20**]) for VAP,
   follow sputum cultures
   # Respiratory failure:
   Likely intubated in order to protect airway in setting of altered
   mental status. Patient is s/p difficult intubation using fiberoptic
   scope for intubation.  Extubated on [**3-12**], required reintubation with
   awake fiberoptic by anesthesia later in the PM on [**3-12**] due to worsening
   tachypnea despite BiPAP.  Mini-BAL performed [**3-13**] with no growth on
   final culture. Patient being maintained on PSV 10/10 now. Ongoing
   diuresis. Any attempt at extubation will require anesthesia on standby
   with airway kit and may require fiberoptic guided reintubation.  New
   c/f VAP given tan colored sputum.  Self extubated on [**3-19**] AM, stable
   resp status post-extubation, placed on BiPAP prophylactically, ABG
   stable.
   - close monitoring of respiratory status.
   - BiPAP as needed
   - follow VBG daily, f/u cultures
   - Cont tx with vanc/zosyn (D1 [**3-20**]) for possible vent assoc PNA, 7d
   course
   - lasix gtt d/c
d yesterday, will watch I/O for continued goal net
   negative.
